text: What is the supreme law of the land?

What is an amendment?

answers.text: the Bill of the Arms Bearing

text: What is one right or freedom from the First Amendment?*
How many amendments does the Constitution have?
What did the Declaration of Independence do?

answers.text: said that the United States is free (from Great Britain)

text: What are two rights in the Declaration of Independence?
What is freedom of religion?

answers.text: You can practice any religion, or not practice a religion.
You can vote only for your local representatives
You understand a faith before you follow it

text: What is the economic system in the United States?*
What is the "rule of law"?

answers.text: No one is above the law.
State laws are over federal laws

text: Name one branch or part of the government.*
What stops one branch of government from becoming too powerful?

answers.text: Legislative and Executive branches controls each other while the Supreme Court is an independent branch.

text: Who is in charge of the executive branch?
Who makes federal laws?

answers.text: The Speaker and The Justice General

text: How many U.S. Senators are there?

Who is one of your state's U.S. Senators now?* (Answers will vary.)

answers.text: [District of Columbia residents and residents of U.S. territories should answer that D.C. (or the territory where the applicant lives) has no U.S. Senators.]

text: The House of Representatives has how many voting members?
We elect a U.S. Representative for how many years?
Name your U.S. Representative? (Answers will vary.)

answers.text: [Residents of territories with nonvoting Delegates or Resident Commissioners may provide the name of that Delegate or Commissioner. Also acceptable is any statement that the territory has no (voting) Representatives in Congress.]

text: Who does a U.S. Senator represent?

answers.text: all people of the New York
all people of Alaska, Floria, New England and South Carolina only

text: Why do some states have more Representatives than other states?

In what month do we vote for President?*
What is the name of the President of the United States now?* (Answers will vary.)
What is the name of the Vice President of the United States now?
If the President can no longer serve, who becomes President?

answers.text: The head of the Defense department

text: If both the President and the Vice President can no longer serve, who becomes President?

answers.text: The head of the Defense department

text: Who is the Commander in Chief of the military?

answers.text: The head of the Defense department

text: Who signs bills to become laws?

answers.text: The head of the Defense Department

text: Who vetoes bills?

answers.text: The head of the Defense department

text: What does the President's Cabinet do?

answers.text: makes the laws of United States

text: What are two Cabinet-level positions?

answers.text: Secretary of Health and Human Services
Secretary of Housing and Urban Development

text: What does the judicial branch do?

answers.text: decides if a law goes against the Constitution
controls the House and the Senate

text: What is the highest court in the United States?

answers.text: the Supreme Court of Washington D.C.

text: How many justices are on the Supreme Court?
Who is the Chief Justice of the United States now? (Answers may vary.)
Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the federal government. What is one power of the federal government?
Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the states. What is one power of the states?
Who is the Governor of your state now? (Answers will vary.)

answers.text: [District of Columbia residents should answer that D.C. does not have a Governor.]

text: What is the capital of your state?* (Answers will vary.)

answers.text: [District of Columbia residents should answer that D.C. is not a state and does not have a capital. Residents of U.S. territories should name the capital of the territory.]

text: What are the two major political parties in the United States?*

What is the name of the Speaker of the House of Representatives now? (Answers will vary.)
There are four amendments to the Constitution about who can vote. Describe one of them?

answers.text: Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.)
A male citizen of any race (can vote).

text: What is one responsibility that is only for United States citizens?*
Name one right only for United States citizens?
What are two rights of everyone living in the United States?
What do we show loyalty to when we say the Pledge of Allegiance?
What is one promise you make when you become a United States citizen?

answers.text: give up loyalty to other countries
defend the Constitution and laws of the United States
obey the laws of the United States
serve in the U.S. military (if needed)
serve (do important work for) the nation (if needed)
be loyal to the United States

text: How old do citizens have to be to vote for President?*
What are two ways that Americans can participate in their democracy?

answers.text: give an elected official your opinion on an issue
publicly support or oppose an issue or policy

because the British army stayed in their houses (boarding, quartering)
